name: title_plot
system_prompt:
You are an assistant tasked with comparing three lists of movies. For each movie, you are given its: title, plot
    Use your own judgment to determine what information is relevant when assessing the diversity of the lists. 
    You should consider the given title, plot.

    Deliver your descriptions of lists, comparison, and choice of the most diverse list in the following JSON format:

    {
        "list_A_description": string,            # Describe the diversity of the movies in list A
        "list_B_description": string,            # Describe the diversity of the movies in list B
        "list_C_description": string,            # Describe the diversity of the movies in list C
        "comparison": string,                    # Compare the diversity of the lists.
        "most_diverse_list_reasoning": string,   # Explanation of which list you perceive to be the most diverse.
        "most_diverse_list": string              # The list you determine to be the most diverse, either 'A', 'B', or 'C'.
    }

evaluations.prompt:
List A:
TITLE: Bourne Identity, The (2002)
PLOT: A man is picked up by a fishing boat, bullet-riddled and suffering from amnesia, before racing to elude assassins and attempting to regain his memory.

TITLE: Snatch (2000)
PLOT: Unscrupulous boxing promoters, violent bookmakers, a Russian gangster, incompetent amateur robbers and supposedly Jewish jewelers fight to track down a priceless stolen diamond.

TITLE: Bourne Supremacy, The (2004)
PLOT: When Jason Bourne is framed for a CIA operation gone awry, he is forced to resume his former life as a trained assassin to survive.

TITLE: Jurassic Park (1993)
PLOT: A pragmatic paleontologist touring an almost complete theme park on an island in Central America is tasked with protecting a couple of kids after a power failure causes the park's cloned dinosaurs to run loose.

TITLE: Guardians of the Galaxy 2 (2017)
PLOT: The Guardians struggle to keep together as a team while dealing with their personal family issues, notably Star-Lord's encounter with his father, the ambitious celestial being Ego.

TITLE: Others, The (2001)
PLOT: In 1945, immediately following the end of Second World War, a woman who lives with her two photosensitive children on her darkened old family estate in the Channel Islands becomes convinced that the home is haunted.

TITLE: Beautiful Mind, A (2001)
PLOT: After John Nash, a brilliant but asocial mathematician, accepts secret work in cryptography, his life takes a turn for the nightmarish.

TITLE: The Hunger Games (2012)
PLOT: Katniss Everdeen voluntarily takes her younger sister's place in the Hunger Games: a televised competition in which two teenagers from each of the twelve Districts of Panem are chosen at random to fight to the death.


List B:

response.list_A_description: List A shows a diverse range of genres and themes. It includes action thrillers (Bourne Identity, Bourne Supremacy, Snatch), science fiction (Jurassic Park, Guardians of the Galaxy 2), a psychological thriller (The Others), a biographical drama (A Beautiful Mind), and a dystopian adventure (The Hunger Games).  The time periods and settings also vary considerably.
response.list_B_description: List B offers a mix of genres, including science fiction (Guardians of the Galaxy 2), biographical crime (Catch Me If You Can), supernatural thriller (The Others), coming-of-age drama (Moonrise Kingdom), dramedy (Rain Man), superhero action (The Avengers), and musical comedy (School of Rock). The inclusion of a World War II-themed film (Inglourious Basterds) adds historical context. However, the diversity is less pronounced than in List A.
response.list_C_description: List C presents a narrower range of genres compared to List A and B.  It primarily focuses on action and thriller genres (Bourne Identity, Bourne Supremacy, Edge of Tomorrow, War of the Worlds), with the addition of a supernatural thriller (The Others), a coming-of-age drama (Moonrise Kingdom), and a dramedy (Rain Man). The thematic consistency is more apparent in this list.
response.comparison: List A exhibits the greatest diversity in terms of genre, theme, setting, and time period. List B has a decent variety but lacks the breadth of List A. List C is the least diverse, with a more concentrated selection of films within similar genres.
response.most_diverse_list_reasoning: List A stands out due to its inclusion of diverse genres, including action, science fiction, psychological thriller, biographical drama, and dystopian adventure.  The settings and time periods represented also vary significantly, making it the most thematically and stylistically diverse list.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety in genres and themes. It includes war (Saving Private Ryan), psychological thriller (Fight Club), animation (Up), biographical drama (Spotlight), animated family film (Finding Dory), fantasy adventure (Pirates of the Caribbean), science fiction (Ex Machina), and crime (Goodfellas). response.list_B_description: List B has a similar level of genre diversity to List A, with action (Mr. & Mrs. Smith), war (Saving Private Ryan), animation (Monsters, Inc.), science fiction (Ex Machina), psychological thriller (Fight Club), crime (Goodfellas), mystery (Sherlock Holmes), and science fiction (Rogue One). However, it leans more towards action and adventure.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a mix of genres, including war (Saving Private Ryan), action (Mr. & Mrs. Smith), war (Hacksaw Ridge), superhero (Avengers: Infinity War), crime (Goodfellas), science fiction (Maze Runner), crime (Hell or High Water), and science fiction (Rogue One).  The inclusion of war movies is notable, and the overall mix is less diverse than List A.
response.comparison: List A and B have comparable diversity in terms of genre and themes. List C has less diversity than the other two lists, with a noticeable concentration on action and war-related themes. List A stands out slightly due to its broader range of genres and themes, including animation and a more prominent focus on character-driven narratives.
response.most_diverse_list_reasoning: List A exhibits the most diversity because it encompasses a wider range of genres, including animation (Up, Finding Dory), and a more balanced representation of themes. While Lists B and C have some variety, they lean more heavily towards action and war-related films. List A's inclusion of diverse genres and themes makes it the most diverse.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a diverse range of genres and themes. It includes animation (Inside Out), thrillers (Shutter Island, Split), science fiction (The Matrix), drama (Shawshank Redemption, Requiem for a Dream), crime (Pulp Fiction), and a dramedy (Intouchables). response.list_B_description: List B presents a more balanced mix of genres than List C, but less than List A.  It features science fiction (Avatar, WALL-E), drama (Shawshank Redemption, A Beautiful Mind), comedy (Little Miss Sunshine), war (1917), and surrealism (Being John Malkovich).  While there's variety, the themes are somewhat less diverse than List A, focusing more on personal journeys and societal issues.
response.list_C_description: List C has a narrower range of genres and themes compared to List A and B.  It includes science fiction (Avatar, WALL-E), war (1917), drama (Intouchables), surrealism (Being John Malkovich), thriller (Shutter Island), and mystery (Knives Out).  The themes are less varied than List A, with a focus on adventure, interpersonal relationships, and suspense.
response.comparison: List A exhibits the greatest diversity in terms of genre and thematic exploration. List B offers a decent variety, but less so than List A. List C shows the least diversity, with a more limited range of genres and themes.
response.most_diverse_list_reasoning: List A stands out due to its broader spectrum of genres, including animation, thriller, science fiction, drama, crime, and dramedy.  The plots also cover a wider array of themes, from emotional intelligence to societal issues, psychological horror, and addiction.  This combination of diverse genres and thematic exploration makes List A the most diverse.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a diverse range of genres and themes. It includes a crime thriller (The Usual Suspects), a sports drama (Moneyball), an animated film (Shrek 2), an action film (The Bourne Legacy), a romantic comedy (Love Actually), a historical drama (12 Years a Slave), a biographical thriller (Captain Phillips), and a romantic comedy (Bridget Jones's Diary). response.list_B_description: List B is also diverse, but leans more towards action and comedy.  It features a crime thriller (The Usual Suspects), an animated film (Monsters, Inc.), a drama (Good Will Hunting), a thriller (The Accountant), a superhero film (Iron Man 2), a comedy (School of Rock), and a survival drama (The Revenant). The genres are varied, but there's a stronger emphasis on action and adventure compared to List A.
response.list_C_description: List C has a mix of genres, but with a noticeable concentration on action and thrillers.  It includes a crime thriller (The Usual Suspects), a thriller (The Accountant), a romantic comedy (Love Actually), an action film (John Wick: Chapter Two), another action film (The Bourne Legacy), a romantic comedy (50 First Dates), an action film (Now You See Me 2), and a romantic comedy (Notting Hill). While there's some genre variety, the action/thriller elements are more prominent than in List A.
response.comparison: All three lists contain some overlap, notably The Usual Suspects. List A offers the broadest range of genres and themes, including historical drama and biographical thriller elements not found in the other lists. Lists B and C are more focused, with B leaning towards action and comedy, and C towards action and thrillers.  List A's inclusion of diverse settings and time periods further enhances its diversity.
response.most_diverse_list_reasoning: List A stands out due to its wider representation of genres and themes.  It successfully balances different styles of filmmaking, including animation, historical drama, biographical thriller, and romantic comedy, which are not as evenly represented in Lists B and C. The variety in settings and time periods further contributes to its overall diversity.

PLOT: Malcolm Crowe, a child psychologist, starts treating a young boy, Cole, who encounters dead people and convinces him to help them. In turn, Cole helps Malcolm reconcile with his estranged wife.

TITLE: Perks of Being a Wallflower, The (2012)
PLOT: Charlie, a 15-year-old introvert, enters high school and is nervous about his new life. When he befriends his seniors, he learns to cope with his friend's suicide and his tumultuous past.

TITLE: Coco (2017)
PLOT: Aspiring musician Miguel, confronted with his family's ancestral ban on music, enters the Land of the Dead to find his great-great-grandfather, a legendary singer.

TITLE: O Brother, Where Art Thou? (2000)
PLOT: In the deep south during the 1930s, three escaped convicts search for hidden treasure while a relentless lawman pursues them.

TITLE: Shaun of the Dead (2004)
PLOT: The uneventful, aimless lives of a London electronics salesman and his layabout roommate are disrupted by the zombie apocalypse.

TITLE: Love Actually (2003)
PLOT: Follows the lives of eight very different couples in dealing with their love lives in various loosely interrelated tales all set during a frantic month before Christmas in London, England.

TITLE: Gattaca (1997)
PLOT: A genetically inferior man assumes the identity of a superior one in order to pursue his lifelong dream of space travel.

TITLE: Big Hero 6 (2014)
PLOT: A special bond develops between plus-sized inflatable robot Baymax and prodigy Hiro Hamada, who together team up with a group of friends to form a band of high-tech heroes.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety in genre and themes. It includes psychological thrillers (The Sixth Sense, The Silence of the Lambs), action (Ocean's Eleven), animation (Big Hero 6), romance (Love Actually), historical drama (Hidden Figures), zombie comedy (Shaun of the Dead), and adventure (Life of Pi).  The representation of different cultures and time periods is also present.
response.list_B_description: List B has a mix of genres, including animation (Big Hero 6), psychological thriller (The Sixth Sense), zombie comedy (Shaun of the Dead), heist (Ocean's Eleven), coming-of-age drama (The Perks of Being a Wallflower), romance (Love Actually), action-adventure (Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade), and psychological thriller (Black Swan). However, it leans more towards thriller and drama genres.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a blend of genres: psychological thriller (The Sixth Sense), coming-of-age drama (Perks of Being a Wallflower), animation (Coco), comedy (O Brother, Where Art Thou?), zombie comedy (Shaun of the Dead), romance (Love Actually), science fiction (Gattaca), and animation (Big Hero 6). The representation of different cultures and time periods is also present.
response.comparison: List A and C have a broader range of genres and themes compared to List B. While List B includes some variety, it is less diverse than A and C.  List A and C both include animation, psychological thrillers, and romantic comedies, but they differ in other genres included. List A has more action and adventure films, while List C has more comedies and science fiction.
response.most_diverse_list_reasoning: List A exhibits the most diversity because it encompasses a wider array of genres, including action, adventure, animation, comedy, drama, psychological thriller, and historical drama.  It also shows a better representation of different cultures and time periods than the other lists.
